deliberation: I checked for metaphor, hyperbole, and personification. The search command is literal, but the city is grammatically and conceptually treated as a woman, and the claim that no just person can be found functions as rhetorical exaggeration.

instances.english_text: That I should pardon her.
target: Jerusalem / the city as a collective entity
vehicle: a female individual who can receive pardon
ground: capacity to be judged, forgiven, or condemned
posture: YHWH addresses the city as a wayward woman in need of pardon
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is addressed with a feminine pronoun as if she were a woman who can be pardoned, personifying the city/community.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־תִּמְצְאוּ אִישׁ אִם־יֵשׁ עֹשֶׂה מִשְׁפָּט מְבַקֵּשׁ אֱמוּנָה
instances.english_text: If you can find one person, if there is anyone who acts justly, who seeks integrity
target: the actual number of righteous people in Jerusalem
vehicle: the condition of not finding even a single just person
ground: extreme scarcity or functional nonexistence of justice and faithfulness
posture: prophetic exaggeration to stress pervasive corruption
instances.explanation: The condition that not even one just person can be found is a rhetorical overstatement emphasizing how rare integrity is, functioning as hyperbolic metaphor for pervasive injustice.

deliberation: The verse reports literal speech and false oaths. No metaphors, similes, or marked idioms beyond a standard oath formula are present.
I looked for anthropomorphism and imagery. God's 'eyes' seeking faithfulness is an anthropomorphic metaphor, and 'faces harder than rock' is a clear metaphor for stubbornness.

instances.english_text: O LORD, Your eyes [are surely set] toward faithfulness
posture: depicts God in human-like terms to stress his focus on integrity
instances.explanation: God is described as having 'eyes' directed toward faithfulness, an anthropomorphic metaphor portraying divine discernment as human sight.

instances.english_text: They made their faces harder than rock
posture: condemns their stubborn refusal to repent
instances.explanation: Their 'faces' are said to be harder than rock, a metaphor for their extreme stubbornness and insensitivity to correction.

deliberation: I checked whether 'the way of the LORD' is literal or conceptual. It is a standard biblical metaphor of conduct as a path.

instances.english_text: the way of the LORD
target: the pattern of life God requires
vehicle: a path or road one walks
ground: directedness, guidance, identifiable course to follow
posture: evaluates the poor as ignorant of God’s prescribed path of life
instances.explanation: The phrase conceptualizes God’s will and commandments as a 'way' or path to be known and followed, a common conduct-as-path metaphor.

deliberation: I examined the imagery of 'breaking the yoke' and 'snapping the bonds'. These are not literal farm instruments but metaphors for rejecting obligations.

instances.hebrew_text: אַךְ הֵמָּה יַחְדָּו שָׁבְרוּ עֹל נִתְּקוּ מוֹסֵרוֹת
instances.english_text: But they as well had broken the yoke, had snapped the bonds
vehicle: a yoke and bonds used to control draft animals
ground: throwing off control, rejecting restraint, asserting independence
posture: condemns the leaders’ deliberate rejection of divine authority
instances.explanation: The people are portrayed as draft animals who have broken the yoke and snapped their bonds, metaphorically expressing their rejection of God’s rule.

deliberation: I considered whether the animals are literal or stand for invaders. In prophetic diction, lion, wolf, and leopard together function as a composite metaphor for fierce, predatory enemies.

instances.hebrew_text: אַרְיֵה מִיַּעַר זְאֵב עֲרָבוֹת יְשׇׁדְדֵם נָמֵר שֹׁקֵד עַל־עָרֵיהֶם כׇּל־הַיּוֹצֵא מֵהֵנָּה יִטָּרֵף
instances.english_text: The lion of the forest strikes them down, the wolf of the desert ravages them, a leopard lies in wait by their towns; whoever leaves them will be torn in pieces
target: the hostile forces that will attack Judah
vehicle: lion, desert wolf, and leopard lying in wait
ground: ferocity, stealth, inevitability of attack, tearing prey apart
posture: presents coming judgment as inescapable and brutal
instances.explanation: Predatory animals are used as a composite metaphor for the ruthless enemies or judgments that will attack and tear apart the people.

deliberation: I checked for spiritual adultery imagery, but here the adultery is concretized by going to a prostitute’s house, and the verse mostly reads as literal moral accusation without overt figurative markers.
I looked for animal imagery; the people are called stallions, not just compared by 'like', making it an explicit metaphor of lustful behavior.

instances.hebrew_text: סוּסִים מְיֻזָּנִים מַשְׁכִּים הָיוּ אִישׁ אֶל־אֵשֶׁת רֵעֵהוּ יִצְהָלוּ
instances.english_text: They were well-fed, lusty stallions, each neighing at another’s wife
target: the men of Judah and their sexual behavior
ground: unrestrained sexual desire, aggressive pursuit, lack of self-control
posture: strongly disparaging depiction of their adultery
instances.explanation: The men are metaphorically called fat, energetic stallions that neigh after others’ wives, emphasizing their uncontrolled sexual lust.

deliberation: The verse consists of rhetorical questions about punishment, but no metaphor, simile, or special idiom beyond ordinary legal/judicial language appears.
I checked whether 'vines' and 'branches' are literal agriculture. Within the chapter’s focus on Jerusalem, this is vineyard imagery used metaphorically for the people and their corrupt elements.

instances.hebrew_text: עֲלוּ בְשָׁרוֹתֶיהָ וְשַׁחֵתוּ ... הָסִירוּ נְטִישׁוֹתֶיהָ כִּי לֹא לַיהוָה הֵמָּה
instances.english_text: Go up among her vines and destroy; lop off her trailing branches, for they are not of the LORD
target: the population of Jerusalem, especially corrupt elements
vehicle: vines and trailing branches in a vineyard
ground: being planted and belonging, yet subject to pruning or destruction when unfruitful or wild
posture: calls for purging unfaithful people as a vintner prunes a vineyard
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s people are portrayed as vines and offshoots in a vineyard; the command to destroy vines and cut branches depicts removing corrupt members from among the people.

deliberation: The verse states that Israel and Judah have 'betrayed' God; this is strong covenantal language but not embedded in a specific metaphorical image like marriage here, so I did not count a discrete figurative expression.
I examined 'sword and famine'; these are literal covenant curses, but 'sword' in particular functions metonymically for warfare, and the pair represents comprehensive disaster.

instances.english_text: We shall not see sword or famine
target: national experience of war and its attendant hardships
ground: the sword stands for warfare and military invasion; famine stands for siege and deprivation
posture: quotes the people’s denial of comprehensive judgment
instances.explanation: Here 'sword' functions metonymically for warfare and violent conflict, and paired with 'famine' it evokes the full range of covenant curses associated with war.

deliberation: I looked for imagery in the description of the prophets. They are said to 'become wind', which is a metaphor of emptiness and lack of substance.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהַנְּבִיאִים יִהְיוּ לְרוּחַ וְהַדִּבֵּר אֵין בָּהֶם
instances.english_text: The prophets shall become wind, for the word is not in them
vehicle: natural force with no solid content
ground: emptiness, lack of weight or reliability, transience
posture: dismisses their prophecies as utterly empty and unsubstantial
instances.explanation: Calling the prophets 'wind' metaphorically portrays their oracles as empty and devoid of God’s true word.

deliberation: I focused on the fire imagery. God’s words in Jeremiah’s mouth are likened to fire, and the people to wood, a tight metaphor for the destructive power of the prophetic word.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי נֹתֵן דְּבָרַי בְּפִיךָ לְאֵשׁ וְהָעָם הַזֶּה עֵצִים וַאֲכָלָתַם
instances.english_text: I am putting My words into your mouth as fire, and this people shall be firewood, which it will consume
target: Jeremiah’s prophetic proclamation and its effect on the people
ground: irresistible consuming power, destruction of what is burned
posture: asserts the lethal, judging force of the prophetic word
instances.explanation: God’s words are metaphorically fire and the people are wood; the image portrays the prophetic word as a consuming, destructive force against the unrepentant people.

deliberation: The nation from afar, its age, and unknown language are all literal descriptions of an invading power; no distinct figurative expression stands out.
The mention of the quiver 'like an open grave' marked by כ is a simile, emphasizing deadly capacity and perhaps insatiability.

instances.english_text: Their quiver is like a yawning grave
target: the military capacity of the invading nation, especially its arrows/weapons
vehicle: death receptacle ready to receive corpses
ground: readiness to kill, capacity to send many to death, gaping openness
posture: heightens the horror of the invader’s violence
instances.explanation: The enemy’s quiver is explicitly compared to an open grave, a simile that underscores how their weaponry leads many to death.

deliberation: I considered whether the repeated 'devour' is literal. It is conventional prophetic language for total destruction: they do not literally eat sons and daughters, making this metaphorical and somewhat hyperbolic.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאָכַל קְצִירְךָ וְלַחְמֶךָ יֹאכְלוּ בָנֶיךָ וּבְנוֹתֶיךָ יֹאכַל צֹאנְךָ וּבְקָרֶךָ יֹאכַל גַּפְנְךָ וּתְאֵנָתֶךָ
instances.english_text: They will devour your harvest and food, they will devour your sons and daughters, they will devour your flocks and herds, they will devour your vines and fig trees
target: the enemy’s destruction of Judah’s people and resources
ground: total consumption, leaving nothing, violent taking in
posture: portrays the invaders as voracious consumers of everything Judah has
instances.explanation: Describing the enemy as 'devouring' not only produce but also sons and daughters is a metaphorical and hyperbolic way to depict complete destruction of people and resources.

deliberation: The declaration of not making a full end is straightforward and not couched in figurative imagery.
Serving foreign gods versus serving foreigners in a foreign land is an ironic reversal but conceptually quite literal; I did not isolate a metaphor or simile here.
I checked 'House of Jacob' for figurative use. 'House' is a metonym for family/nation, a conventional expression for the descendants of Jacob.

instances.english_text: to the House of Jacob
ground: a house stands for those who dwell in it, especially the family line
posture: addresses the nation in familial terms
instances.explanation: The 'House of Jacob' uses 'house' metonymically to refer not to a building but to Jacob’s family line, i.e., the nation.

deliberation: I noted multiple cognitive-body metaphors: having 'no heart' for lack of understanding, and having eyes/ears yet not seeing/hearing for spiritual insensitivity.

instances.english_text: O foolish people, devoid of heart
target: the people’s capacity for moral and spiritual understanding
vehicle: having or lacking a physical heart
ground: the heart as seat of thought and will in Hebrew anthropology; lacking it suggests absence of discernment
posture: denounces their lack of inner moral sense
instances.explanation: Saying the people are 'without heart' metaphorically depicts them as lacking the inner organ of understanding and will, i.e., devoid of sound judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: עֵינַיִם לָהֶם וְלֹא יִרְאוּ אׇזְנַיִם לָהֶם וְלֹא יִשְׁמָעוּ
instances.english_text: They have eyes but do not see; they have ears but do not hear
target: the people’s spiritual perception and responsiveness
vehicle: physical seeing and hearing with eyes and ears
ground: having functioning senses implies capacity to perceive; failure to 'see/hear' signifies willful unresponsiveness
posture: portrays them as culpably unresponsive despite full capacity
instances.explanation: Although they literally have senses, their refusal to heed God is metaphorically described as blindness and deafness, signaling spiritual insensitivity.

deliberation: The description of the sea bounded by sand, its waves tossing and roaring, is vivid but essentially literal depiction of God’s control over nature, not a metaphor for Israel here.
I examined 'wayward heart' and 'they turned aside and went'. The key figurative element is the path metaphor: moral rebellion as turning aside and walking away.

instances.english_text: They have turned aside and gone their way
target: the people’s moral and religious behavior
vehicle: turning off a path and walking elsewhere
ground: changing course, leaving the proper route, pursuing an alternative trajectory
posture: frames their rebellion as deliberate departure from the proper path
instances.explanation: Their disobedience is portrayed as physically turning aside from the right road and going away, a metaphor for abandoning God’s prescribed way.

deliberation: I checked for idioms. 'They have not said in their heart' is a Hebrew idiom for inner reflection/resolution; the rain and harvest references are literal.

instances.english_text: They have not said in their heart
target: the people’s internal decisions and attitudes
ground: inner deliberation conceptualized as talking to oneself internally
posture: criticizes their failure to internally resolve to fear God
instances.explanation: The phrase 'say in the heart' is an idiomatic way to speak of inner reflection or resolve, not literal verbal speech inside an organ.

deliberation: I looked at 'have diverted these things' and 'have withheld the good', which treat sins as if they physically deflect and block blessings—metaphors of obstruction.

instances.hebrew_text: עֲוֺנוֹתֵיכֶם הִטּוּ־אֵלֶּה וְחַטֹּאתֵיכֶם מָנְעוּ הַטּוֹב מִכֶּם
instances.english_text: It is your iniquities that have diverted these things, your sins that have withheld the bounty from you
target: the causal relationship between sin and loss of blessing
experience of withheld rain and prosperity
vehicle: turning aside something and holding back good
ground: sin functions like a barrier or deflector, preventing good from reaching the people
posture: explains deprivation in terms of moral causation, visualized as blockage
instances.explanation: Their sins are said to 'divert' and 'withhold' blessings, a metaphor that pictures sin as a barrier physically blocking good things from reaching them.

deliberation: I checked predatory imagery. Evildoers are explicitly compared to fowlers lying in wait through כ, a clear simile of ambush and trapping.

instances.hebrew_text: יָשׁוּר כְּשַׁךְ יְקוּשִׁים הִצִּיבוּ מַשְׁחִית אֲנָשִׁים יִלְכֹּדוּ
instances.english_text: Who lurk like fowlers lying in wait; they set up a trap to catch people
target: wicked members of the people and their predatory behavior
vehicle: fowlers hiding and setting snares for birds
ground: secrecy, deceit, waiting to ensnare unsuspecting victims
posture: exposes the wicked as clandestine trappers of humans
instances.explanation: The evildoers are said to lurk 'like fowlers', a simile portraying them as hunters who secretly set snares to catch human victims.

deliberation: The verse uses an explicit כ-comparison: a cage full of birds is like their houses full of deceit, a straightforward simile of accumulation of fraud.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּכְלוּב מָלֵא עוֹף כֵּן בָּתֵּיהֶם מְלֵאִים מִרְמָה
instances.english_text: As a cage is full of birds, so their houses are full of guile
target: the contents and character of the wicked’s households
ground: being filled to capacity with something, containing many trapped items
posture: depicts their homes as repositories of fraud
instances.explanation: Their houses are compared to a birdcage crammed with birds, a simile that depicts their domestic spaces as stuffed with deceit and plunder.

deliberation: I noted two distinct images: (1) becoming 'fat and sleek' as metaphor for prosperous, self-indulgent corruption, and (2) 'passing beyond the bounds of evil' as a boundary metaphor for exceeding normal wickedness.

instances.english_text: They have become fat and sleek
target: the moral and socio-economic condition of the leaders
vehicle: physical fatness and sleekness of the body
ground: overindulgence, complacency, comfort leading to callousness
instances.explanation: Their moral and economic corruption is portrayed as physical obesity and sleekness, a metaphor for overfed, self-satisfied wickedness.

instances.english_text: They have even passed beyond the bounds of wickedness
target: the extent of their evil behavior
vehicle: stepping past a limit or boundary line
ground: going beyond a set limit signifies excess, surpassing what is normally tolerated
posture: emphasizes that their evil exceeds ordinary wickedness
instances.explanation: Their actions are depicted as crossing a boundary line of evil, a metaphor that presents their wickedness as excessive beyond normal limits.

deliberation: This verse repeats the rhetorical question about punishment. It is forceful but not framed in distinct metaphorical or idiomatic phrasing.
The 'appalling and horrible thing' is an evaluative description of what follows; no particular metaphor or simile is used in this short statement itself.
I examined the phrase 'rule by their hands'. 'By the hand of' is a common Hebrew idiom and metonymy, where 'hand' stands for power or agency.

instances.english_text: and the priests rule by their hands
target: the manner in which priests exercise authority, aligned with false prophets
vehicle: the hand as an instrument of action and control
bodily member used for doing things
ground: the hand stands metonymically for power, agency, and means
posture: criticizes priests for ruling by the agency/influence of lying prophets
instances.explanation: The phrase 'by their hands' uses 'hand' idiomatically and metonymically for agency or power, indicating that priests rule under or through the prophets’ influence.
